question: A solid cube of mass m at a temperature <katex>$\theta_{0}$</katex> is heated at a constant rate. It becomes liquid at temperature <katex>$\theta_{1}$</katex> and vapour at temperature <katex>$\theta_{2}$</katex>. Let <katex>$s_{1}$</katex> and <katex>$s_{2}$</katex> be specific heats in its solid and liquid states respectively. If <katex>$L_f$</katex> and <katex>$L_{v}$</katex> are latent heats of fusion and vaporisation respectively, then the minimum heat energy supplied to the cube until it vaporises is
explanation: Heat steps: Solid heat (<katex>$\theta_0 \to \theta_1$</katex>) + Fusion (<katex>$mL_f$</katex>) + Liquid heat (<katex>$\theta_1 \to \theta_2$</katex>) + Vaporisation (<katex>$mL_v$</katex>).
